results.summary:
Between 30 April and 2 May 2025, there were a cascade of extreme weather events from overflow of rivers to flash floods: 18 people injured, 4,429 households (approximately 22,145 individuals) were affected within KwaZulu Natal (KZN), Northwest, Northern Cape. At least 1,000 households with impacted houses (significant damages) identified as being in urgent need of humanitarian assistance. Eighteen people were also reported injured across the affected regions.
In the Northern Cape, intense rainfall in that period triggered a historic surge in the Orange River. On 02.05.2025, Water flow at Augrabies Falls reached catastrophic levels of 4,000 cubic metres per second—nearly 80 times the seasonal average. Overall, the flooding impacted 1,139 households (5,695 individuals) in the province. Hardest hits include In Ga-Segonyana municipality, 141 households (705 individuals) were directly affected by the floods.
That event cumulate with the floods early recorded on 30 April 2025 in the Northwest province. The province experienced severe flooding due to the Vaal River breaching its banks after exceeding capacity. In total, over 1,300 households (approximately 6,500 individuals) were affected in the province. The overflow of water completely flooded 160 households In Ramotshere Moiloa municipality, while in Ngaka Modiri Molema municipality, hundreds of individuals had to be evacuated in centers.
results.name: ZAF: Floods - 05-2025 - South Africa floods

field_reports.summary: ZAF: Complex Emergency - Eastern Cape Floods and KwaZulu Natal Tornado
field_reports.description:
P

Parts of the Eastern Cape especially Nelson Mandela and Buffalo City Metros experiences heavy rains accompanied by strong winds early hours of the 2nd of June 2024 which resulted in severe flooding in most parts. Over the weekend, the South African Weather Service issued a yellow level 6 warning with predictions of strong winds, snowfalls and flooding in parts of the Western Cape, KwaZulu Natal, Northern Cape and the Eastern Cape.  In addition, dam walls were compromised and canals were unable to deal with heavy rainfall which resulted in water flooding into homes and businesses. So far more than 10100 people (2030 households) have been affected including 2500 people have been displaced and 7 people have lost their lives to the floods and a number still reported missing. https://www.sanews.gov.za/south-africa/condolences-eastern-cape-flood-victims-0 The heavy rains resulted in flash floods especially in the 2 Metros (Nelson Mandela Bay and Buffalo City) wreaking havoc in affected areas. https://www/heraldlive.co.za/news/2024-06-03-heavy-rains-wreak-havoc-in-nelson-mandela-bay  About 70 people have been rescued in 55 operations since Sunday, according to the National Sea Rescue Institute (NSRI). People have been evacuated to town halls and schools, however, some families are refusing to relocate because they are concerned over their belongings. https://mg.co.za/news/2024-06-03-six-people-dead-and-hundreds-evacuated-in-eastern-cape-floods/

 

In addition, on the 3rd of June 2024 a tornado resulted in adverse floods which affected more than 16244 people and displaced more than 1200 people in KwaZulu Natal Province mainly in Ethekwini, uMkhanyakude, uMzinyathi, King Cetshwayo, Ugu and Amajuba districts resulting in a total of 7358 households destroyed. https://www.sabcnews.com/sabcnews/946183-2/ A total of 3 shelters have been established accommodating a total of 731 people. As of today, 14 people lost their lives in KwaZulu Natal due to the tornado that hit the province late afternoon on the 3rd of June 2024 https://allafrica.com/stories/202406050036.html

In the Sarah Baartman District Municipalities the areas that are adversely affected by the floods include Kouga area – Sea Vista, Oyster Bay, Jeffreys Bay, Thornhill and in Ndlambe area – New Rest Infomral Settlement was also affected. School has been disrupted, there are water interruptions and there are electricity interruptions with households not having these two basic services since Sunday. The dam wall near Lapland or Tyriville is currently being assessed as there are fears it will collapse causing further flooding in areas. Bridges have collapsed along the Rocklands Road as well as Matanzima road in Kwanobuhle. It must be noted that many people who have lost their homes and belongings are not at community halls but are residing with family members in Kariega. The areas affected include Kuyga, Kwadwesi, Qunu, Langa and Greenfirelds, Kariega Central and Kamesh, Missionvale, Gerald Smith, De Mist, Doctor Brawn, Eric Dodd. Missionvale, Walmer, Witteklip, Daleview, Kwanoxolo, Vastrap, Jachtvlakte, Rocklands, Zwelidinga, Rosedale, GMV, Riemvasmaak, Kleinskool, Joe Slovo, Lapland and Tyriville.

 

In addition, Buffalo City Metro has been adversely affected leaving 2200 people displaced with the following areas affected, Duncan Village, Amalinda, Gompo, Mdantsane, Stoney Drift, Kelly Road, Vincent Park, Pfefferville. Damages are also reported in Ngqushwa, Great Kei LM and Amahlati. It is worth noting that figures would possibly rise as assessments are ongoing and more information continues to be received.

results.summary:
The South African National Government announced that the 7th National General Election will take place on the 29 May 2024. These elections are anticipated to be the most fiercely contested since the establishment of democracy in 1994. The Voter registration was closed on 23 February 2024 followed by roll objections on the 4 March 2024 and candidate nominations were adjusted then submitted by political parties and independent candidates on 08 March 2024. Voting stations were announced on 12 April 2024 leading to special voting on 27-28 May 2024.

The 2024 general elections in South Africa are set against a backdrop of significant socio-political tension, with heightened risks of electoral violence that could impact lives, livelihoods, well-being, and infrastructure across various regions.

1) High-risk areas such as Gauteng, KwaZulu-Natal (KZN), the Eastern Cape, and parts of the Western Cape are particularly vulnerable. Gauteng, with its dense urban centres like Johannesburg and Pretoria with a history of fatal political clashes, are of special concern.

2) Medium-risk provinces such as Limpopo, Mpumalanga, and North West have experienced sporadic disturbances, which, while generally less severe, still require vigilant monitoring.

Conversely, the Free State and Northern Cape are considered low-risk areas due to their historically peaceful elections.

The electoral landscape is informed by historical data which shows that while the 1994 and 2004 elections were largely peaceful, the 2021 local government elections identified 300 hotspots of potential violence, underscoring the ongoing challenges.

The direct impacts of electoral unrest are most acutely felt by vulnerable groups including the elderly, children, people with disabilities, internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugees, and residents of informal settlements. These groups are at a heightened risk of suffering due to their socio-economic conditions, reliance on community and government support, and proximity to politically sensitive areas. Historical precedents indicate that election periods marred by social unrest and violence have not only led to loss of life and injuries but also caused significant disruptions to economic activities and access to essential services, thereby exacerbating the vulnerabilities of already marginalized groups.
results.name: ZAF: 05-2024 Election preparedness

results.summary:
In South Africa, natural disasters such as floods, severe storms have led to significant social and economic losses, which is anticipated to exacerbate as consequence of climate change. On the 7th of January 2024 to date, storm surge which resulted in flooding affected KwaZulu Natal and Free State province. Overall, 1,226 households(6,418 people) were affected.

In the KwaZulu-Natal province approximately 814 households (4,297 people) were affected as per the preliminary report from the Government. According to the reports by Government, 41 fatalities(including 21 from Ladysmith) have been confirmed, and 4 people still missing in KwaZulu Natal province. The heavy storms have affected different districts in KwaZulu Natal, especially uThukela (Ladysmith), uMzinyathi, Amajuba district Municipality where fatalities were reported due to drowning, same displaced and other people still reported missing.

On the other hand, the Free State province has encountered unprecedented and remarkable levels of precipitation, accompanied by severe thunderstorms and destructive winds, resulting in extensive damage to households in formal and informal settlements within the Mangaung, Lejweleputswa, Thabo Mofutsanyane, Fezile-Dabi, and Xhariep district, farmers within have lost crop damages within the Mangaung Metro Municipality and the Thabo Mofutsanyane area since the 7th and 8th of January 2024 and adverse weather conditions continue exposing vulnerabilities a storm surge accompanied with flooding occurred in Ficksburg and Jaggersfontein and affected almost 412 households (2,121 people). Currently displaced people are accommodated by friends, relatives and neighbors.

results.summary:
Severe weather between Sept. 23-26 resulted in flooding, loss of life and displacement of residents, severe damage on private and public infrastructure, road closures, and power outages across Western Cape province. The severe weather and flooding have affected at large group of people in the and around the city, including eight fatalities due to electrocution by illegal electricity connections. Damage assessments are ongoing, but initial reports indicate more than 1,500 structures impacted by flooding. The Kuils River overflowed, flooding Mfuleni Township and forcing around 2,710 families to evacuate. Reports also indicate evacuations in Faure and Sandvlei. Over 16,000 people have been reported to be affected by the floods.

This is whilst 7,100 informal structures were adversely affected. According to News 24, it reported 11 fatalities in the affected areas. Furthermore, there are reports of nearly 250 schools which are affected by the disaster.

The Bot River overflowed in the town of Botrivier, flooding large parts of the N2 Highway and cutting off road access.

Flooding also resulted in closures across other highways, including parts of the N1, R60, and R62. More than 100,000 people in Western Cape Province were without power at the height of the storm. Authorities have not restored power to most people, and around 15,000 remain without electricity as of Sept. 27.

Authorities in Cape Town issued a major incident declaration due to the flooding. Flooding and associated disruptions are still ongoing across Western Cape Province.
results.name: ZAF:2023-10 Floods in Western Cape

field_reports.summary: ZAF: Other - 2023-06 - South Africa Cholera Outbreak
field_reports.description:
Recently there has been a cholera outbreak in Hammanskraal which was noticed from the 15th of May 2023 by health officials at local district health centre (Jubilee hospital) in Hammanskraal, north of Pretoria, according to the Gauteng Department of Health (GDoH). Significant rise of cases was witnessed from the 21st of May 2023 and unfortunately twenty-three (23) people have lost their lives since the cholera outbreak 77 patients were still admitted for the waterborne disease. It is worth noting that 29 patients have since recovered and were discharged,” the provincial department said. https://reliefweb.int/report/south-africa/cholera-death-toll-climbs-23-hammanskraal

In line with the above, the poor infrustructure in public centres like schools, day care centres, taxi ranks etc, pose a great threat for the spread due to limited infrustructure to promote good hygiene practices like handwashing. There is need for strengthened community engagement by intensifying Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) and ensure that communities are proactive to seek medical assistance when they notice symptoms related to cholera. Moreso, rumors, myths and perceptions need to be addressed through community feedback mechanism.

field_reports.summary: ZAF: Flood - 2022-12 - Flash Floods in Gauteng and North West Province
field_reports.description:
Parts of Gauteng province and North West province were negatively affected by the recent floods that hit hardest areas like parts of Soweto, Johannesburg, Vereeniging, Brakpan  and Bojanala in the North west Province on Saturday the 10th   and the 11th of December 2022. This followed media release by South African Weather Service (SAWS) on Friday the 9th of December 2022. https://www.weathersa.co.za/Documents/Corporate/Medrel_9_December_HD_09122022132545.pdf

South African Red Cross Society (SARCS) intensifies dissemination of early warning messages to at risk communities. Although dissemination efforts were done to minise the impact of floods to at risk communities the average rainfall which the province have been receiving the past week resulted in soil saturation. This resulted in flash floods as there was more water run-off with minimum drainage

Following the joint rapid assessments coordinated by Gauteng and North West Provincial Disaster Management Centres (PDMCs) in collaboration with other government sector Departments which include Department of Social Development (DSD), Department of Home Affairs, South Africa Social Service Agency (SASSA) and South African Red Cross Society (SARCS) revealed that so far 3826 households have affected (3326 in Gauteng and 500 in North West) and about 10 000 people have been displaced. The affected people have been evacuated to safer areas which include community halls and educational centres. The mostly affected areas like Kliptown, Protea South, Bram fisher, Nancefield Hostel and Lenasia in Soweto, Alexandra in Johannesburg and Bojanala in North West are currently cut off from electricity connection and infrastructure like roads to connect them to markets are flooded. The Joint Operations Coordination (JOC) team in the district has been activated.

field_reports.description: The South African Red Cross Society (SARCS) conducted joint assessments with government through its local municipalities, disaster management centers at both district and provincial levels. A total of   17 households were destroyed completely and 243 households partially destroyed resulting in a total of 250 households affected and assessments are ongoing. Many families have lost their household items due to the mudslides or had to leave without being able to take them with them. The infrastructure such as water and electricity supply are impacted yet based on the initial assessment, services remain restricted. SARCS continues to actively participate in Joint Operations Committee (JOC) which are spearheaded by both provincial and district Disaster Management Centres to ensure well-coordinated response and recovery interventions which minimize duplication of efforts to same communities whilst other communities are still in need. Several people have sought refuge from friends, family, and other are staying at 3 established evacuation centres. This is posing great risks of the spread of respiratory diseases. Due to the environmental risk from the mudslide, this might lead to contamination of water supply thus increasing the risk of waterborne diseases in the community. Some family members suffered psychosocial trauma due to the impact of mudslides.The mudslide has greatly affected health, WASH, food security and livelihoods sectors and people are struggling to cope with ripple effects which include trauma, stress, limited hygiene materials and food insecurities. Based on above, this DREF request will focus on supporting the urgent needs of affected communities which include psychosocial first aid (PFA), food, hygiene materials, and replacing lost essential household items like kitchen utensils, blankets and clothes

field_reports.description:
The South Africa Weather Service (SAWS) release Easter weekend weather predictions on the 13th of April 2022 and upper trough expected to intensify further, resulting in the development of an extensive band of isolated to scattered showers and thundershowers over much of the central interior. Consequently, KwaZulu Natal, North West, Free State, Eastern Cape are likely to experience the return of thunderstorms, along with the risk of localised flooding and/or occurrences of hail and strong, damaging winds. This is adding great strain to existing flood impact which the province has been experiencing since it was hit hardest by worst floods midnight of the 11th of April 2022.

The joint rapid assessments conducted by government and stakeholders including South African Red Cross Society (SARCS within the province in 10 affected districts in the 10 affected districts are ongoing. Search and rescue teams are still active in the field and death toll has risen to 395 https://www.enca.com/news/kzn-floods-death-toll-increases-395 . So far, the adverse impacts of recent floods in KwaZulu Natal (KZN) has resulted in estimated 40 723 people affected and more 11 976 households destroyed and 264 schools destroyed. The floods impacts in KZN has resulted in displaced people to be clustered in 24 evacuation centres which were identified by the government. https://www.citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/3077609/kzn-floods-over-40k-people-affected-as-fatalities-rise/ This also make the affected people to be more vulnerable limited limited food, electricity and water supply, waterborne diseases, mental health due to stress of losing their belongings and loved ones. Other areas of KZN have been characterised by protests as some of the affected communities show their frustrations especially of clean water supply and electricity which is not available in most of the seriously affected districts

field_reports.summary: ZAF: Flood - 2022-04 - South Africa Floods in KwaZulu Natal
field_reports.description:
According to South Africa Weather Service (SAWS), KwaZulu Natal experienced the worst floods following overnight of 11 April 2022 were rainfall reports have underscored the particularly heavy and extreme nature of the rainfall, with some 24-hour falls exceeding 200 mm. More noteworthy, is that a few stations even reported 300 mm or more! A selection of the highest overnight rainfall measured in KwaZulu-Natal includes King Shaka International Airport (225 mm), Margate (311 mm), Mount Edgecombe (307 mm), Port Edward (188 mm) as well as Virginia airport (Durban 
north) with 304 mm. Such rainfall is of the order of values normally associated with tropical cyclones; however, SAWS strongly emphasised that this system is not tropical in nature, nor is it a tropical cyclone.

The above resulted in 10 districts of KwaZulu Natal namely uMkhanyakude, uthukela, uMzinyathi, uMgungundlovu, Zululand, Ethekwini, iLembe, Harry Gwala, King Cetswayo, Ugu and Amajuba being negatively affected by the impact of floods resulting in more than 6 705 people being affected and more  1341 households being totally destroyed, 2030 people displaced and 253 fatalities recorded so far. This has resulted in displaced people to be clustered in evacuation centres with some being seperated from their loved ones and 3 reported missing. This also make the affected people to be more vulnerable to waterborne diseases, mental health due to stress of loosing their belongings and loved ones. Most of the areas are not yet accessible so numbers are expected to rise.

field_reports.description:
According to South African government Eastern Cape Provincial Disaster Management Centre (PMDC), the thunderstorm which commenced from the 12th of December 2021 has caused devastating effects especially in OR Tambo, Afred Nzou, Chris Hani and Buffalo city district municipalities. This followed after early warning by South African Weather Service (SAWS) on the 10th of December of Level 4 which was later described that it had a strong wind in excess of about 60km per hour. The continuous joint assessments which are being conducted by government through its local municipalities, disaster management centres and stakeholders which include the South African Red Cross Society, reveals that a total of 1110 households (5550) people were affected by thunderstorm.  All affected areas have not yet been reached as the thunderstorm continues and numbers of affected households continues to increase as assessments are still underway. So far there has been 6 confirmed death cases and 27 serious injuries which resulted in injured people to be admitted in government hospitals. Some of the affected population's shelter were completely destroyed and others are partially destroyed posing more risk of unsafe shelter especially with continuous heavy rains still experienced in affected areas. More so, some of the affected populations have lost their food stock and livelihoods especially flock (sheep, goats an d chickens). This expose the affected populations to high levels of food insecurities and risks of COVID-19 infections as some are accomodated in evacuation camps were they are crowded and not having hygiene materials to use. Some have been accommodated by friends and relatives who are also grappling with the impact of COVID-19 impacts and not easy to meet their basic needs too.

In addition, a total of 4 bridges and access road have been washed away. A total of 8 schools and 1 clinic were also destroyed in different districts increasing the vulnerabilities of affected communities.

results.summary:
Urban violence has been ongoing in South Africa, with a peak from 9 to 17 July 2021, in response to the arrest of former President. The riots triggered wider rioting and looting fueled by high unemployment rate, poverty and economic inequality, worsened by the COVID-19 pandemic. The civil unrest began in the province of KwaZulu-Natal on 9 July, and spread to the province of Gauteng on 11 July 2021. As of 16 July, 212 people had died in the unrest and 2,554 had been arrested. The riots and looting resulted in food shortages, fuel shortages and medical supply shortages. Kwa Zulu Natal and Gauteng account for more than half of South Africa's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and during the riots on the 12 July, the Rand, local currency, weakened by about 2% affecting the economy. More than 200 shopping centres in South Africa have been looted and property destruction costs are reported to be above 1 billion USD according to a RepublicWorld.Com, a local online news outlet.

Other services affected are the medical and pharmaceutical retailers, while hospital services were also disrupted. COVID-19 vaccine rollout sites were closed to prevent looting and property destruction, which has a negative impact and is delaying the National vaccination process.

field_reports.description:
The predicted storm is likely to affect 3 provinces namely, Limpopo and Mpumalanga Provinces as well as northern KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa on Sunday, 24 January 2021 and continuing into Monday, 25 January 2021. Possible impacts as a result of all this rain include widespread flooding, damage to roads and bridges as well as possible displacement of affected communities. This system is likely to result in Gauteng and North West provinces also receiving some rainfall on Monday and Tuesday, however at this stage such rainfall is not expected to be of an extreme or damaging nature or result in the impacts mentioned above.
SAWS has highlighted that, it is important to note that the accurate prediction of the track (or path) of tropical weather disturbances is very challenging indeed. Tropical weather systems are notorious for their often erratic and unpredictable movement. SAWS will therefore continue to closely monitor this system and will keep the public advised via regular updates across a variety of media platforms.

field_reports.description: In South Africa, untamed fires are on the rise in informal settlements and in low-income neighborhoods, in and around the country’s cities. Recently, on the 24 of August 2020, Kwa Zulu Natal province has experiencing shack fires in the informal settlements. The affected municipalities are uMngeni Local Municipality and eThekwini Metro Municipality. The incident in Umngeni Local Municipality (Howick) resulted from the paraffin stove that was left on whilst the shack owner was asleep. The incident in Durban was caused by the candle that was left on by the household owner in one of the shacks. Shacks in the informal settlements are closer to one another and this makes it difficult to extinguish fires during the fire break out incident as there is not much space for movement. The above tragic was experienced in Howick and Durban, leaving the community members severely affected by the fire incident.
